question_text: Based on the provided paper content, explain the synergistic catalytic effects observed in carbon nanotube (CNT)-supported catalysts like Ag/CNTs for RDX decomposition, focusing specifically on the mechanisms that are explicitly supported by the experimental evidence in the citations.
standard_answer: The synergistic catalytic effects of CNT-supported catalysts like Ag/CNTs in accelerating RDX decomposition arise from complementary mechanisms between the CNT support and metal nanoparticles. The high specific surface area and porous structure of CNTs provide extensive adsorption sites that concentrate RDX molecules near catalytic centers, enhancing reactant availability. The CNT support prevents nanoparticle agglomeration, maintaining high surface area and active site density for sustained catalytic activity. As explicitly stated in the paper: 'Ag/CNTs nanocomposite was prepared and its catalytic effect on decomposition of RDX was investigated. It was indicated that the irregularly globose nano-Ag particles attached to the surface of the nano CNTs evenly, forming a promising composite catalyst for RDX.' This uniform distribution creates optimal conditions for catalytic interaction. Furthermore, the paper notes that 'The synergistic effect of the CNTs with carried catalysts may greatly improve catalytic activity, and the agglomeration problem of nano-sized catalysts may be improved as well.' This demonstrates that the CNT structure enhances catalytic performance by both providing structural support to prevent catalyst particle aggregation and creating a synergistic environment where the combined system exhibits greater activity than either component alone. The prevention of agglomeration ensures sustained high surface area, while the uniform distribution of Ag nanoparticles on CNT surfaces maximizes catalytic sites accessible to RDX molecules.
